• The jointing structure includes multiple steps with an expansion gap between them, elastic members mounted inside these steps, and a joint block placed over the elastic members to bridge the expansion gap. This design helps maintain smooth and safe vehicle travel by preventing tire fall-in and stuck-in situations.

• The elastic members used in the structure are primarily made of laminated rubber, designed to be hard to deform vertically but easy to deform horizontally. This allows the joint block to remain centered over the expansion gap even during shifts caused by temperature changes or seismic events, thus maintaining a continuous and level travel path.

• The invention also describes a method for mounting the elastic members, which involves fixing one side of the elastic member first, deforming it towards the bridge girder axis, and then fixing the other side. This method ensures that the elastic members are optimally positioned to accommodate bridge movements without requiring readjustments for temperature or time of day.

• The design includes variations such as using high-strength fiber-reinforced concrete for the joint block and supporting blocks to increase durability and slip resistance, and configuring the expansion gaps obliquely to further reduce tire fall-in risks for smaller vehicles. The components are designed to be detachable for easier maintenance and replacement.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to floor track systems used in sanitary fluid treatment chambers for transporting food stuffs, specifically cooked meat products, on wheeled hand trucks.
• Traditional air chilling methods for meat products cause dehydration and slow heat transfer, leading to issues like difficult casing removal and product shrinkage.
• Recent methods involve using a chilled brine solution in fluid treatment chambers to quickly cool meat products, allowing for the heat to be efficiently transferred and the brine to be recirculated, saving resources.
• The invention addresses the need for a sanitary environment as required by regulations, such as those from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and aims to process large quantities of meat efficiently.
• Previous systems used overhead rails which limited movement routes and could contaminate the brine solution with lubricants from the transport wheels.
• The invention proposes a floor transport system using wheeled dolly-like floor trucks that can move freely without contaminating the brine solution, overcoming the limitations of fixed overhead systems.
• The enclosed floor track system is designed to prevent the wheels of the trucks from coming into contact with the brine solution, thus maintaining its sanitary condition for reuse.
• The system includes a wheel channel raised above the floor by support legs, with a cover plate to prevent brine from entering the wheel area, and is designed for easy cleaning.
• Another embodiment uses inflatable seals to enclose the wheel channel, preventing brine entry and providing a braking mechanism to stabilize the trucks on an inclined track.
• The invention enhances the recovery and reuse of brine, prevents corrosion and deterioration of truck components, and eliminates the need for decontaminating the brine solution, offering economic and environmental benefits.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a lock device designed to prevent the downward rotation of a boom in construction machinery, specifically a backhoe, due to its own weight.
* The lock device includes an engaging member and an engaged member, which can be manually operated to lock the boom in place, preventing accidental movement during travel or when not in use.
* The design features a support pin and guide member that help maintain the lock device in either a locked or unlocked position, with various surfaces and slots to facilitate smooth operation and prevent damage from friction and wear.
* The invention aims to simplify the locking mechanism, reduce the number of parts and assembly processes, and extend the lifespan of the components by minimizing abrasion and rust.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a swimming pool vacuum cleaning apparatus designed to allow precise regulation of suction efficiency by adjusting the vacuum head's proximity to the pool bottom, addressing the limitations of prior art devices which lack real-time suction adjustment capabilities.
• The vacuum head features adjustment mechanisms located on top for easy operation without tools, enabling quick and precise regulation of suction without adjusting the remote suction source, enhancing usability for commercial pool cleaning operators.
• The design includes a flexible platform with a central suction portion, outboard and inboard roller assemblies with adjustable heights, and a handle assembly for maneuvering the vacuum head across the pool bottom.
• The apparatus can be retrofitted to existing pool cleaning devices with minor modifications, offering an adjustment mechanism in kit form that includes frames, connectors, wing nuts, coil springs, and axles for easy installation.
• Detailed descriptions and illustrations (FIGS. 1-10) provide a comprehensive view of the apparatus, including its components and assembly, demonstrating the innovative features that allow for the precise control of suction and adaptability to various pool conditions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention pertains to oil well drilling tools, specifically an apparatus designed for retrieving wear bushings from well heads and casings.
* Wear bushings are used in drilling to protect well head elements and casing heads from excessive wear during drilling operations.
* Existing technologies, such as those described in U.S. Pat. Nos. 3,747,914 and 3,489,214, involve methods for wear bushing retrieval using bits or specific engagement mechanisms like J-slots and dowels.
* The new invention offers a solution to retrieve wear bushings without needing to remove the drill bit, addressing limitations in current methods where rigid engagement can damage the bushing or make retrieval difficult.
* The apparatus includes a sub-unit with a mandrel that can be mounted between drill pipe sections, featuring a retriever section that can move vertically but not rotate independently.
* The retriever section has protruding members that engage with a J-slot in the wear bushing, allowing for secure attachment and retrieval.
* The design allows for about 3 feet of vertical "play" or movement in the retriever section, preventing damage from misalignment during retrieval.
* The apparatus can be easily installed and removed from the drill string, facilitating quick replacement of wear bushings during drilling operations.
* Drawings included in the patent illustrate the assembly and operation of the apparatus, showing how the retriever section engages with the wear bushing.
* An alternative embodiment of the retriever section features a threaded end for engaging with correspondingly threaded wear bushings, simplifying the retrieval process.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to downhole vibratory tools designed to dislodge stuck objects, known as "fish," in wellbores.
* Traditional vibratory tools lacked a central passageway for wireline operations, requiring removal of the tool to run diagnostics or other tools.
* Recent advancements include a drop-in dart design allowing wireline access through the tool, but this design compromises on the size and durability of components.
* The new tool design features an annular dump valve that keeps the central passage clear, allowing wireline operations without removing the vibratory tool.
* The tool uses stacked pistons to increase power delivery, enhancing the force transmitted downhole to dislodge the fish.
* The design prevents the dump valve from slamming against a seat, reducing wear and potential failure.
* The tool can be operated in a vibratory mode by dropping a removable plug onto a seat, initiating the vibration process.
* Modular piston design allows customization based on specific downhole conditions and required power levels.
* The tool's operation involves a cycle of pressure build-up and release, controlled by the movement of a mandrel driven by pressure-activated pistons.
* The innovative design improves reliability, reduces maintenance costs, and allows for continuous wireline access, enhancing operational flexibility in downhole conditions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a precast concrete retaining wall system designed for use alongside highways and railways, aiming to address limitations of traditional retaining wall designs by allowing for taller walls with shorter bases.
* Traditional retaining wall systems often require extensive space and time for installation due to the need for large tieback elements and on-site concrete pours. This invention simplifies the process by using pre-manufactured components that are assembled on-site, reducing both time and cost.
* The retaining wall comprises two main precast components: a face panel with integral counterforts and a solid base. These components are designed to connect easily on-site without the need for temporary shoring, and can handle immediate wind loads once assembled.
* The design includes features to enhance stability and durability, such as drainage systems within the counterforts, multiple options for anchoring the base to the ground, and the potential integration of vehicle impact barriers either on top or behind the wall.
* The system is flexible in terms of customization, allowing for variations in the size and shape of components to meet specific project needs, and it can be adapted to various ground conditions by incorporating elements like H-piles or grouted connections.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention pertains to systems and methods for heating oil or gas at the down hole end of production tubing to improve production flow, particularly useful for wells with high viscosity oil or paraffin blockages.
* Existing down hole heating technologies often fail due to inadequate protection against intense pressures and corrosive environments, leading to electrical shorts and component corrosion.
* The new design focuses on overcoming these failures by ensuring that heat is concentrated in the production zone and that the heating elements are insulated from up hole components to prevent heat loss.
* Key components of the system include electrical resistance heater rods, a heat insulating packer, stainless steel tubing collars, and a specially designed heating unit that is resistant to physical and chemical damage.
* The heating unit's electrical connections are protected by a cement block made of high temperature epoxy and encased in a steel fitting assembly, ensuring long-term operation without failure.
* The invention also includes a method for using the heating system in oil and gas wells, which can be adapted for use with a wire line during well treatments or maintenance, offering potential benefits for deep gas wells with specific occlusion issues.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention pertains to down hole tools used for mechanical activities in wells, specifically designed for the efficient installation and removal of objects, including those that are stuck or lost within a well bore.
• It improves upon existing technologies by providing a mechanism that allows for easy connection and disconnection to down hole objects or "fish," enhancing the effectiveness of fishing operations typically conducted with wire line controlled tools.
• The tool features a telescoping inner and outer body structure with a catch mechanism that facilitates locking and unlocking positions through simple linear movements, enabling easy retrieval or release of objects without excessive force or jarring.
• Detailed descriptions and illustrations of the tool's components and operation are provided, including various embodiments and modifications that cater to different well servicing needs and conditions, ensuring versatility and adaptability in field operations.
</summary>

<summary>
• The document relates to a patent application for a method of manufacturing composed stave floors, claiming priority from earlier applications filed in Mexico and under the PCT in 2011.
• The invention addresses issues with conventional composed stave floors, such as the thinness of the sight substrate which leads to deformation, detachment, and reduced durability after maintenance.
• The sight substrate in conventional floors is typically made from de-rolled wood, which tends to curl back to its original form, affecting the floor's aesthetics and functionality.
• Conventional assembly methods using glue alone have drawbacks like long curing times and the need for uniform pressure and level surfaces during assembly.
• The proposed method includes using a sight substrate with a minimum thickness of 4 mm and a base substrate with a minimum thickness of 12 mm, improving durability and maintenance capabilities.
• The assembly involves multidirectional holding means including dendrites, adhesion, horizontal and vertical reinforcement means to enhance the bond between the substrates.
• The new floor design aims to preserve the physical, aesthetic, and functional properties of the floor, prevent deformation, and extend the useful life of the floor.
• The document also discusses the application of pre-varnished glazes that enhance durability without compromising the floor's appearance.
• Example embodiments and tests are described, comparing the new floor design to conventional floors, showing improvements in preventing detachment and deformation.
• The document includes several figures illustrating both conventional and new floor designs, highlighting the differences and improvements made in the new method.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention pertains to ladder attachments designed to enhance stability, prevent surface damage, and maintain a safe distance from the work surface.
• The ladder attachment includes a brace with an extension arm and a flange that connects to the ladder's rungs using a U-bolt, ensuring the ladder's lateral stability.
• A pivotal resilient pad assembly is connected to the extension arm, which can pivot vertically or horizontally, allowing the ladder to securely straddle corners without losing stability.
• The design aims to increase the contact area between the ladder and the work surface, using a broad, non-slip pad that prevents damage like dents or scrapes.
• The brace assembly can be adjusted and securely tightened to accommodate different ladder sizes and types, including less sturdy materials like aluminum or fiberglass.
• The invention addresses common issues with traditional ladders, such as limited stability and potential damage to work surfaces, making it suitable for various applications like painting or window washing.
</summary>

<summary>
* This document details a continuation-in-part of U.S. patent applications related to a collated nail strip invention, specifically designed for use in fastener driving tools in the construction industry.
* The invention focuses on a collated nail strip made from a debris-free plastic material, which adheres to the nails, reducing debris when nails are driven into a substrate like wood.
* The plastic material used is an adhesive polymer, such as a blend of polypropylene and maleic anhydride modified polypropylene, which is molded onto the nails preheated to temperatures between 450° F. and 600° F.
* The collation system includes features like a collar portion that encircles the nail shank and a connecting portion between nails, which can have a cruciform shape or an embossed pattern to enhance rigidity and minimize debris.
* Various configurations of the nail strip are discussed, including adjustments to the positioning of the collar on the nail shank, the use of tapered collars, and the incorporation of weakened regions to control where the strip separates when a nail is driven.
* The document also explores the benefits of the invention, such as improved penetration and holding strength of the nails, reduced generation of debris, and potential configurations for different applications, including coiled nail strips.
</summary>

<summary>
* This document details a patent application for a novel nozzle design used for applying sealants like silicones in various industries including aviation, automotive, naval, railway, and robotics.
* The nozzle features a bell or hood-shaped lower section and an injection button, designed to improve the precision and versatility of sealant application.
* The application claims priority from a previous European Patent Application and is the national stage of an International Application filed under the PCT.
* The nozzle is particularly useful for encapsulating rivets or screws during manufacturing processes, ensuring a precise and clean application of sealants.
* The injection button of the nozzle has a special design with multiple channels and orifices that guide the sealant for precise application around rivets and nuts.
* The nozzle can be connected to both manual cartridges and automated injection machines, enhancing its utility across different settings.
* Drawings included in the patent application illustrate various embodiments of the nozzle, showing its components and how they interact.
* The nozzle is designed to be non-permanently attached to the sealant delivery system, allowing for easy installation and removal.
* The document describes two embodiments of the nozzle, each with unique features to suit specific applications and preferences.
* The invention aims to provide a more efficient, precise, and safer method for applying sealants, reducing labor time and improving the quality of the applications.
</summary>

<summary>
• This document details a patent application related to position and motion sensors, specifically for mechanical systems like diesel engine fuel injectors, which require monitoring and control of moving parts for efficient operation.
• The invention aims to improve sensor systems by reducing wiring complexity and energy consumption through a method of multiplexing signals from multiple sensors over a minimal number of wires.
• The sensors described operate on a two-wire system, utilizing changes in current proportional to the position of the monitored object, which simplifies the wiring and reduces the overall system cost and weight.
• The document introduces a sensor system that includes a waveform generator and an error correction generator. These components work together to condition the sensing signal by removing unnecessary power and static signals, thereby optimizing the sensor's performance.
• A detailed description of the electronic circuit implementation is provided, explaining how the system handles error correction, signal conditioning, and recalibration upon power-up to ensure minimal current draw and accurate operation.
• The sensor system is designed to be robust against noise and capable of rapid recalibration in response to sudden environmental changes, making it suitable for high-demand applications such as in automotive or industrial settings.
</summary>

<summary>
• This document details a patent application for a desmodromic valve actuation system designed for internal combustion engines in automobiles, aiming to improve efficiency and control in the intake and exhaust functions of a four-stroke piston engine.
• The system claims to enhance engine performance by eliminating the need for springs in valve control, which traditionally limit engine speed and efficiency due to their mass and required force for compression.
• The invention describes a system where valve actuation is controlled by a combination of a rotating cam and a translating means, allowing for precise, variable control of valve positions and the percentage of port opening.
• The system is designed to be computer-controlled, enabling adjustments to valve positions in real-time based on engine performance requirements, thus optimizing fuel consumption and engine output.
• The valve actuation mechanism described uses a rotary cam with a grooved track that interacts with a translating slider mechanism, which in turn controls the valve's linear motion, allowing for variable valve positioning.
• The document outlines potential configurations for different engine setups, including options for controlling multiple valves per cylinder through a single camshaft, which simplifies the engine design and reduces the need for multiple camshafts and complex timing alignments.
• The proposed system is described as robust and simple in construction, potentially reducing manufacturing, assembly, and maintenance complexities compared to traditional valve actuation systems.
• Overall, the invention aims to provide a more efficient, reliable, and adaptable valve control system for internal combustion engines, contributing to better fuel economy and enhanced engine performance.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document details a continuation patent application related to aquarium lighting systems, specifically using LED technology. It builds on earlier applications and claims priority from a provisional application filed in 2013.
* The invention includes a light member with a housing that has a top side facing away from the aquarium and a bottom side facing the interior, equipped with a lighting control region for different light colors and a neutral channel.
* The light member can accommodate multiple light-emitting modules that emit different colors (e.g., white and blue) and are controllable via switches on the housing. These modules are designed to be easily attached or detached from the lighting control region.
* The document describes various configurations of the light member, including options with multiple lighting control regions and the ability to control light settings via RF remote control, allowing for adjustments in color and intensity.
* Additional features include in-line timers for automated control over lighting conditions, options for adjusting light angles and intensities using optical elements, and the potential for different LED configurations to achieve desired effects.
* The technology is adaptable for other uses beyond aquariums, such as under-cabinet lighting in kitchens or offices, with modifications to suit these environments.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention pertains to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for high-temperature fluid-flow machines, such as gas turbines, improving upon existing designs.
* Traditional flow deflection apparatuses like rotor blades use internal cooling channels with cooling fluid, but face issues like high material temperature, thermal stresses, and complex casting processes.
* The invention proposes using separate inserts for the separating walls in the cooling channels instead of casting them as a single unit with the blade.
* These inserts can be made from metal or non-metal materials and are designed to reduce blade weight, simplify manufacturing, and alleviate thermal stresses.
* The inserts are introduced into the blade post-casting and can be secured by methods like soldering or welding, offering flexibility in design and maintenance.
* Preferred embodiments include the use of U-shaped separating walls to direct cooling fluid and holders in the form of rails for easy insertion and secure attachment of the inserts.
* The invention simplifies the blade's core casting process, reduces production scrap, and allows for easy adjustment of the cooling system by replacing or modifying the inserts.
* The document also includes detailed descriptions and comparisons with prior art, highlighting the advantages and innovative aspects of the new design.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention pertains to a fuel delivery system for vehicles that allows switching between automatic and manual control of the throttle valve, aiming to enhance fuel efficiency and reduce emissions without compromising vehicle safety or performance.
* The system includes a control unit that processes signals from the accelerator pedal and throttle valve to control a motor (stepper or DC) that adjusts the throttle valve position. It features a clutch mechanism for manual control and integrates smoothly with continuously variable transmissions.
* The invention addresses shortcomings in previous systems by ensuring smooth transition between control modes and maintaining full vehicle operation capability in manual mode, unlike systems that limit speed during manual control.
</summary>

<summary>
• This document details a division of application Ser. No. 885,377, filed Mar. 10, 1978, now U.S. Pat. No. 4,177,740, focusing on a waste fuel burner designed to efficiently burn wood waste with minimal environmental impact.
• The invention addresses the inefficiencies and pollution issues associated with traditional wood waste burners, commonly known as hog fuel burners, which produce excessive particulate and gaseous emissions.
• The new burner design aims to emit very minimal quantities of particulate materials, operate effectively with wet wood of up to 70% moisture content, and produce little to no slag or clinkers.
• The system incorporates a primary and secondary combustion chamber design where the primary chamber uses controlled underfire air to dry and gasify the fuel, and the secondary chamber completes combustion with additional air to ensure clean exhaust.
• Swirl air and secondary combustion air are introduced tangentially to enhance particulate separation through centrifugal forces, preventing slag formation and maintaining clean gas output.
• A unique flame holder and pressure isolator are used to manage gas flow and particulate return to the primary chamber, ensuring efficient combustion and minimal particulate escape.
• The described burner can also be adapted for use with other particulate-laden combustible gases from various industrial processes, such as coking operations, to meet environmental standards.
• The system allows for rapid response to changes in load, with a capability to adjust from high to low output quickly, which is crucial for applications like boilers that require quick adjustments to heat output.
• The design includes features to extend the life of the system components, such as cooling passages for the refractory linings and controlled combustion environments to prevent excessive temperatures and wear.
• The burner's efficient operation allows for smaller boiler designs and the potential for industrial applications beyond heating, such as in kilns and dryers, by adjusting the exhaust temperature through additional air blending.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document details an evaporative refrigeration system that efficiently cools air without increasing its moisture content, using a heat exchanger to separate the evaporating water from the cooling air stream. The system recycles air from the room (working air) through the wet side of the heat exchanger and uses fresh air for the dry side, enhancing cooling efficiency and energy conservation.
* Several embodiments and improvements are discussed, including a hybrid system that integrates a vapor compression refrigeration unit to further cool and dehumidify a portion of the air, and various configurations of the heat exchanger and air flow paths to optimize performance and reduce energy consumption compared to traditional vapor compression systems.
</summary>

<summary>
* This document details a patent application related to advanced fluid pumps, specifically designed for high volumetric flow rate and high pressure applications, such as pumping liquid manure from agricultural reservoirs.
* The application claims priority from an earlier U.S. patent application and references another U.S. Patent Publication for a related pump technology.
* The described fluid pump includes multiple pump heads (at least two) arranged in series, each containing an impeller within a housing that drives fluid through multiple conduits, combining into a single flow.
* A unique drive structure is used to commonly drive the impellers of all pump heads, enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of the pump system.
* The pump assembly can be mounted on various support structures such as a wheeled boom, a hitching assembly, or a trailer, making it versatile for different operational environments.
* Detailed descriptions and illustrations (figures) are provided to explain the components and assembly of the pump, including the configuration of impellers, drive shafts, and fluid conduits.
* The document emphasizes the novelty and utility of the pump design, which cannot be achieved by simply stacking known pumps, highlighting its innovative approach to managing high-pressure and high-flow fluid pumping challenges.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention pertains to engine compression release brakes, specifically for engines where not all cylinders are equipped with these brakes, enhancing engine robustness by reducing unnecessary components.
• Traditional systems use a brake for each cylinder, but this invention uses brakes on only some cylinders, as full braking power may not always be necessary.
• The engine includes an engine housing with multiple cylinders, but compression release brakes are installed on only a portion of these cylinders.
• The system involves a method where brakes are attached to some cylinders, which are then operated in a braking mode to achieve the desired braking power.
• The engine features a hydraulic system powered by a high-pressure pump that circulates oil from a low-pressure reservoir, with an electronic control module managing various engine operations including brake timing.
• Each cylinder has a piston that moves through intake, compression, power, and exhaust strokes, with the compression release brakes integrated into the exhaust valves of selected cylinders.
• The braking mechanism involves a solenoid-activated valve that controls the hydraulic pressure to an actuator, which then mechanically opens the exhaust valve during the compression stroke to release compressed air and achieve braking.
• The system's design allows for flexibility in the number of cylinders with brakes, depending on the desired braking power, making it adaptable to different engine sizes and requirements.
• The invention also considers various modifications and configurations of the braking system to suit different engine designs and installation spaces.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention pertains to a mounting link between an engine structure and an auxiliary gearbox, specifically designed to handle extreme loads such as those from blade-off events in aircraft gas turbine engines.
• Blade-off events, where engine blades detach, create unpredictable and severe shocks that can damage the gearbox and connected systems, potentially leading to dangerous oil leaks.
• The link assembly includes a male link and a female link, which couple either to the engine or the gearbox, allowing for controlled translation and dampening of movement through a radial interface.
• A pin is used to releasably couple the male and female links, providing selective retention and allowing for controlled separation under extreme loads.
• The gearbox assembly is designed to attach to an engine and includes various components like driveshaft connections and peripheral load connections, which support auxiliary systems like generators or air circulation systems.
• The mounting links and a seal constrain the gearbox in all six translational and rotational degrees of freedom, preventing overconstraint which could lead to damage during impacts.
• The pin in the mounting link acts as a fusible link, designed to shear under extreme loads, thus protecting the gearbox and engine by allowing relative movement between the linked components.
• Post-event, the pin can be replaced during maintenance, making the system reusable and reducing the need for extensive repairs.
• The design aims to limit damage to the gearbox and its peripherals by absorbing shocks and preventing detachment from the engine, while also reducing the need for excessively heavy reinforcement.
• The system's effectiveness is enhanced by the coulomb damping provided by the radial interface between the male and female links, which dissipates energy during translation.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention improves archery equipment by introducing a point cap and balance pin system that attaches arrow points and nocks to arrow shafts without internal stress, preventing damage and allowing for adjustable weight for better balance.
* The point cap system uses external threads and materials like hardened steel or aluminum to reduce stress at the arrow shaft ends, and can be replaced if damaged, protecting the more expensive arrow shaft.
* Balance pins, made of heavy metals like brass, can be trimmed to adjust the weight of the arrow point, ensuring perfect balance and performance of the arrow.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a military training device that simulates the sound and flash of small arms fire using an electronically controlled pyrotechnic system, designed to enhance the realism of battlefield training without using live ammunition.
• It features a low-cost, plastic expendable housing with metal/oxidizer pyrotechnic charges and an electrical ignition system, which can be inserted into a weapon like a magazine, making it cost-effective and safe for training purposes.
• The device interfaces with the weapon's existing mechanisms, such as the trigger and bolt, and includes safety features that prevent firing when the weapon bolt is open or the simulator is not properly installed.
• The electrical control circuit includes multiple components like oscillators, counters, decoders, and firing control systems to manage the timing and sequence of pyrotechnic charges, ensuring realistic firing simulation.
• The simulator is compatible with the Multiple Integrated Laser Engagement System (MILES) for enhanced training feedback and realism, and is designed to fit within the form factor of an M16 magazine for seamless integration.
• The pyrotechnic charges are contained in individual cups within the expendable, which are ignited electrically to produce sound and flash, simulating actual gunfire while maintaining safety through controlled pressure and venting systems.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to an air intake device for internal combustion engines designed to optimize engine performance by utilizing dynamic air flow effects, while also reducing intake noise.
• The device includes a tank connected by two pipes with different cross-sectional areas to the air intake passage, a control valve, and a valve actuating mechanism responsive to engine conditions.
• The smaller pipe acts as a resonator to absorb noise, and the larger pipe adjusts the effective length of the intake path to enhance volumetric efficiency and performance at various engine speeds and loads.
• The control system for the valve uses inputs from engine speed and throttle position sensors to optimize the timing of the valve's operation, improving efficiency and reducing noise based on engine load and speed.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention describes a two-part mounting bracket designed for easy and versatile installation of speakers or other equipment on various surfaces, including poles and walls. It allows for one-person installation, adjustable positioning, and is suitable for outdoor use with its robust, weather-resistant design featuring stainless steel components and minimal parts for economic efficiency.
• The bracket system includes a stationary bracket that attaches to the mounting surface and an adjustable bracket for the equipment, which snaps together with the stationary bracket using integrated hooks and tabs for a tool-free temporary mount, followed by secure attachment using screws for final adjustment. Additional features include pole adapters for various pole sizes and a chain-based tension system to prevent rotation and slippage.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a versatile and efficient combustion burner designed for use with various modular heat utilizing appliances such as cookers, smokers, and heaters.
* The burner features a combustion chamber with a fuel holder, surrounded by an outer wall and a shroud that directs air for secondary and tertiary combustion, enhancing efficiency and reducing emissions.
* Key components include a pivotally coupled ash pan and food grate, manual couplings for attaching modular appliances, and a cover to prevent accidental contact with heat and emissions.
* The system supports interchangeable appliances, allowing the burner to be adapted for different functions like cooking, smoking, space heating, and pyrolyzing, using a variety of solid fuels.
* Additional features include a constricted exhaust outlet for heat concentration, air dampers for airflow control, and legs to elevate the burner above ground level, facilitating easy ash removal and air intake adjustments.
</summary>

<summary>
* Rotary internal combustion engines are being improved for better fuel economy and durability, focusing on the water cooling system which is crucial for managing engine temperature and preventing housing distortion.
* The most severe cooling issues occur around the spark plug areas, where uneven heating can lead to thermal fatigue or cracks, potentially reaching the water jacket.
* Dual in-line spark plugs have been used to improve combustion by ensuring complete burning of the air-fuel mixture, but this setup disrupts the flow of cooling fluid, leading to heat accumulation.
* Spark plug bosses, which are integrated into the water jacket, help in heat dissipation but can also hinder the cooling flow, especially in rotary engines where these bosses are closely positioned.
* The invention aims to enhance both ignition and cooling systems to maintain efficient combustion and reduce the risk of structural failures by improving the cooling characteristics around the spark plug bosses.
* The new design features staggered spark plug bosses that allow better coolant flow and heat distribution, reducing the likelihood of overheating and improving the overall cooling efficiency of the engine.
* Detailed descriptions and schematic illustrations (FIGS. 1-6) show the differences between the new staggered arrangement and the traditional in-line setup, highlighting the benefits in coolant performance and heat transfer.
* Experimental results confirm that the staggered boss configuration significantly increases the heat transfer coefficient, leading to a more controlled and efficient cooling process around critical engine components.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention focuses on a method to minimize flow disturbances in turbines caused by the periodic testing of turbine control valves, which involves closing and reopening these valves. This method uses the positions of the control valves as feedback to maintain constant steam boiler pressure and turbine power during testing.

• Traditional methods for managing inlet pressure and turbine power disturbances during valve testing are inadequate because they allow inlet pressure changes and require modifications to existing systems. The new method maintains total mass flow through parallel turbine inlet flow control valves constant, thus stabilizing the system without needing additional process parameter monitoring.

• The method calculates total mass flow based on the position of the control valves (valve stem lift) and adjusts the flow characteristics of the remaining valves when one is closed for testing. This adjustment is based on pre-determined flow characteristics for different numbers of operational valves, ensuring minimal disruption to turbine operation.

• Detailed descriptions and diagrams illustrate the system's operation, including graphs showing flow characteristics with different numbers of valves and block diagrams of the control circuits used to implement the method. These help in understanding how valve positions are adjusted during testing to maintain desired flow rates.

• Real-time simulations and tests demonstrate that the method significantly reduces pressure fluctuations during valve testing, with a noted reduction in pressure excursion by 95% when compared to systems without this flow compensation method. This confirms the effectiveness of using valve position feedback for flow disturbance minimization during turbine control valve tests.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention pertains to a mixing valve designed for an aircraft cleaning apparatus, capable of combining fluids from two separate sources (inlets A and B) to produce a range of mixtures from 100% of one fluid to 100% of the other.
• The valve system is particularly useful in the commercial airline industry for facilitating the cleaning of aircraft by teams, allowing multiple users to control the strength of the cleaning solution without interference.
• The valve includes a body with defined inlet and outlet passages, and an adjustable valve mechanism that allows for continuous control over the mixture proportions of the two fluids.
• The design includes a spool valve with various components that manage the flow and mixing of the fluids, ensuring that the mixture can be adjusted from all of one fluid to all of the other.
• The system is designed to maintain constant pressure and flow rates, even when multiple units are used simultaneously from the same fluid sources, thanks to specific features like flow restricting devices and bore size adjustments.
• Safety features such as check ball valves are suggested to prevent backflow and potential contamination between the soap solution and water sources.
• The detailed description and drawings illustrate the construction and operation of the valve, emphasizing its utility in providing precise control over cleaning solution mixtures in a high-pressure environment.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention pertains to a method and arrangement for compressing gas in compressor stations along pipelines, particularly in permanent frost areas, which involves compressing the gas to a higher pressure, cooling it, and then reintroducing it into the pipeline at a lower temperature and increased pressure.
* The invention addresses the challenges of cooling compressed gas during warmer periods by using a method that compresses the gas to an excess pressure, cools it, and then expands it to achieve further cooling to the desired exit temperature, thus avoiding the need for expensive and risky re-cooling plants.
* The compressor station setup includes multiple stages of compression and cooling, with the option to use expansion turbines during expansion for additional cooling and energy recovery, which is particularly beneficial during summer operations.
* The system is designed to be flexible, allowing for different operational modes depending on seasonal temperature variations, which optimizes energy use and operational costs throughout the year, and reduces investment and operational risks compared to traditional re-cooling technologies.
</summary>

<summary>
* Electronic components generate heat during operation, and in many cases, free convection cooling is insufficient, necessitating the use of electric fans to enhance air movement and prevent overheating.
* Cooling fans are typically integrated into an enclosure housing the electronic components and are mounted using fasteners such as screws, which increases the cost due to labor and tool requirements.
* The document describes a system that eliminates the need for traditional fasteners in securing cooling fans to enclosures, applicable in various industries like automotive and computing.
* The cooling fan assembly includes a motor to rotate a fan blade, with the motor potentially being electric or non-electric (e.g., hydraulic, pneumatic) depending on the application.
* The motor is housed in a non-rotatable housing that is integrated with a motor carrier, which includes resilient mounting legs that engage with a panel through a series of openings and recesses.
* Installation of the cooling fan assembly involves inserting the mounting legs into corresponding openings on the panel and applying a combination of compressive and rotational forces to lock the assembly in place.
* The design ensures that the fan assembly remains securely mounted and minimizes vibrational noise and movement through the use of spring members that exert an urging force, keeping the assembly stable during operation.
</summary>

<summary>
* Spacecraft structures often use lightweight composite materials that lack sufficient damping characteristics, leading to high vibration levels during flight that can jeopardize the functionality of mounted instruments.
* Current efforts focus on modifying graphite structures in spacecraft to reduce vibration, but additional vibration reduction techniques may be needed if these modifications prove insufficient.
* The invention introduces kinematic mounts with novel damping features, incorporating passive energy dissipating mechanisms to protect instruments from damaging flight loads, using materials like viscoelastic damping material and titanium alloy.
* The design simplifies manufacturing by using six identical strut elements, potentially arranged in a way to uncouple the mount suspension modes, improving performance and reducing costs.
</summary>

<summary>
* This document details a division of a patent application for an oil shear type clutch unit, primarily used in large power transmission systems like aircraft catapults, which addresses issues like high horsepower transmission, cooling, and minimizing residual drag.
* The clutch unit features a unique design with interleaved clutch plates and discs, hydraulic fluid for actuation and cooling, and individual piston and cylinder mechanisms for each clutch disc segment to reduce residual drag significantly.
* The clutch system includes a sophisticated control system with multiple stages of fluid amplifiers and a servo control valve to ensure precise control of the clutch operation based on various environmental and operational parameters.
* The design allows for easy maintenance and replacement of clutch disc segments without disassembling the entire unit, utilizing segmental disc arrangements and auxiliary fluid passages that also aid in cooling and reducing operational drag.
</summary>

<summary>
• The document details a continuation application for an engine system that incorporates multiple cylinders, including combustion and expansion cylinders, to improve energy efficiency by capturing and reusing exhaust heat and water. The system claims to potentially eliminate the need for a radiator in associated vehicles by optimizing the use of heat and reducing exhaust temperatures.

• Innovations include the use of catalytic materials within the engine to convert impurities directly, gearing between cylinders to optimize output, and a water recovery system that reuses water injected into the cylinders for cooling and steam generation. Various embodiments and configurations of the engine system are described, showing different methods of integrating these features.

• The system aims to achieve high thermal-to-mechanical energy conversion efficiency by minimizing heat loss through advanced designs such as using water-lubricated materials in cylinders, insulating hot surfaces, and potentially eliminating the radiator. Detailed descriptions of the water cooling and recovery systems suggest methods to manage and reuse heat and water effectively within the engine system.
</summary>

<summary>
• The document details a continuation of U.S. patent applications related to the fabrication of coated steel plates intended for welding and heat treatment to produce parts with high mechanical strength and corrosion resistance, particularly for automotive applications.

• It describes a method where steel plates coated with aluminum or aluminum alloy are used, and prior to heat treatment, the coating is heated to form a surface alloy by interdiffusion, which prevents decarburization and oxidation, eliminating the need for special atmosphere furnaces and certain surface treatments.

• The invention addresses issues with welding coated steel blanks where the coating can melt and form intermetallic areas in the weld, reducing joint deformability. The proposed solution involves removing a precise portion of the coating before welding to prevent these issues and ensure good corrosion resistance.

• The document outlines a specific composition for the steel used in the plates, including detailed percentages of carbon, manganese, silicon, and other elements, aiming to optimize the mechanical properties and quenchability of the final parts.

• Various methods for removing the metal alloy layer from the steel plates are discussed, including mechanical brushing and laser ablation, with a focus on ensuring that the intermetallic alloy layer remains intact to protect against corrosion and maintain the integrity of the welded joints.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document is a continuation of a prior U.S. patent application and details a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system for navigating energy-extracting vessels in marine environments.
* The invention addresses the limitations of stationary energy recovery systems by enabling mobile structures to navigate and operate in hazardous offshore environments, optimizing energy extraction from wind and water currents.
* The SCADA system utilizes an algorithm that integrates data from weather observations and onboard sensors to optimize navigation and energy extraction efficiency.
* Data sources for the SCADA system include GPS, weather satellites from various agencies like NASA and NOAA, and other geographic and weather data systems.
* The system is designed to operate unmanned mobile structures remotely, reducing risks to human crews in extreme weather conditions and making energy recovery economically viable.
* The SCADA system includes servers running secure software applications and client systems with GUIs for remote human interaction, allowing for critical mission planning and adjustments.
* The mobile structures can be various types of energy recovery systems, such as turbine-integrated hydrofoils, floating wind turbines, or systems designed to harness energy from electrical storms.
* The document describes the hardware and software architecture necessary for the SCADA system, including detailed descriptions of control mechanisms, communication systems, and data processing.
* The patent application emphasizes the flexibility and broad application of the SCADA system, not limited to specific types of mobile structures or energy recovery technologies.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention pertains to a rolling body guide cage and a method for its manufacturing, focusing on reducing production costs by minimizing material waste.
* The guide cage is constructed from a ring element made of sheet metal, which is axially profiled and includes multiple guide structures for rolling bodies.
* Traditional manufacturing methods, like those disclosed in DE 1 625 540 A1, involve punching ring elements from sheet metal, resulting in significant material waste.
* The new method involves using flat material ring segments that are joined and welded prior to forming the axial profiling, significantly reducing waste.
* The ring segments are preferably 120° segments, allowing them to be closely punched from a strip of sheet metal, requiring only three weld points for assembly.
* The segments are joined via an engagement zone with joint contours that interlock, providing preliminary coupling before welding.
* Welding is preferably done using laser welding to ensure strong, distortion-free joints.
* Post-welding, the ring segments can be further processed, such as by calibration or additional punching, to achieve the final dimensions and features.
* The invention is applicable to both radial and axial bearing cages, including those for groove and angular ball bearings.
* The process allows for efficient sequential operations in manufacturing, including automated feeding, positioning, and welding of the ring segments.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document details methods and systems for improving telecommunications services by using global satellite positioning to accurately determine customer service locations and provide efficient routing for service technicians. This includes obtaining precise latitude and longitude coordinates for customer locations, updating databases with these coordinates, and using them to guide service technicians directly to service sites, thereby enhancing response times and service efficiency.
* It also describes systems for generating travel directions for technicians moving between multiple service locations, utilizing a combination of technician servers, GPS systems, and mapping systems to provide accurate and efficient routing information. This system ensures that technicians can navigate effectively between jobs, optimizing travel time and improving overall service delivery.
</summary>

<summary>
* This document relates to a patent application for a system designed to compensate electromagnetic interfering fields, specifically magnetic fields.
* The system utilizes two triaxial magnetic field sensors and three pairs of compensation coils, controlled by a digital processor such as a DSP or FPGA.
* The sensors measure the amplitude of interfering magnetic fields in three-dimensional space, which are then processed to generate control signals for the coils.
* The system can compensate both homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields, adapting to changes in the field characteristics.
* Helmholtz coils are used to create homogeneous compensation fields, and the system can adjust the distance between these coils based on the nature of the interference.
* The control unit combines the sensor outputs into a virtual sensor signal using matrix multiplication, which optimizes the compensation based on the location of the object being protected.
* Control algorithms, which can be linear or nonlinear, modify the virtual sensor signals to generate appropriate outputs for the compensation coils.
* The system can handle feedback effects when multiple compensation systems are used in proximity, using a feedback matrix to minimize interference between systems.
* The document includes detailed mathematical descriptions and algorithms for processing the sensor data and controlling the compensation coils.
* Figures and schematic diagrams in the document illustrate the setup and operation of the magnetic field compensation system, including configurations for different types of interfering fields.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document details a method for investigating biological samples using Coherent Anti-Stokes Raman Scattering (CARS) microscopy, which involves detecting a resonance signal generated by laser irradiation of resonance sites in the sample. This method includes enhancing the microscopy by introducing additional resonance sites through bioorthogonal reactions with intrinsic chemical structures of the sample.
* The invention aims to improve the specificity and sensitivity of CARS microscopy, allowing for better imaging of biological samples by equipping samples with resonance sites that are not naturally present or sufficiently distinct. This is achieved by using bioorthogonal chemistry to add or highlight specific molecular structures, thereby facilitating more effective and detailed imaging and analysis.
</summary>

<summary>
* This document details a U.S. provisional application related to medical equipment for radiation therapy, specifically focusing on the precise control of radiation to treat tumors while minimizing damage to surrounding tissues.
* It describes the use of external radiation sources, such as linear accelerators and radioisotopes, which are collimated to target only tumorous sites from multiple angles and intensities to optimize treatment plans.
* Advanced radiation delivery modalities are discussed, which involve modulating individual "beamlets" of radiation to conform doses to target regions while limiting exposure to non-target areas.
* The document highlights the use of volumetric medical imaging, like CT and MRI, to create a digital model of the patient's anatomy, aiding in the radiation treatment planning through segmentation of target and sensitive areas.
* It introduces an invention for assessing radiation therapy segmentations by comparing different segmentation sources, including a "gold standard" set by experienced clinicians against those by trainees or software systems.
* The system uses electronic files to generate volume models from segmentations, which are then compared to identify discrepancies in volume elements, aiding in quality assurance and evaluation of segmentation routines.
* The comparison process involves a computer executing a stored program to analyze the segmentations, identify common, missing, and extra volume elements, and output a measure of conformance based on a metric method.
* The document also describes the computer setup necessary for implementing the invention, including hardware components like a processor, memory, and graphic display, and software components for executing the comparison and displaying results.
* Various interfaces and user interactions are detailed, showing how users can load segmentation files, select metric methods, and view graphical representations of segmentation comparisons to assess and improve segmentation quality.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document discusses related U.S. patent applications and the background of floating point operations in data processing systems, highlighting the complexity and time required for addition and subtraction operations in floating point format.
* It describes the disadvantages of traditional floating point operations, particularly the need to align fractions and normalize results, which prolongs the execution time.
* The invention aims to improve the efficiency of floating point operations, specifically focusing on accelerating the effective subtraction operation by using a subset of operand exponent arguments.
* The document outlines a new method where the difference between a subset of the operand exponent arguments is used to initiate subtraction operations earlier, thus speeding up the process.
* Several figures (FIG. 1 to FIG. 7) are referenced, illustrating the relationship between addition and subtraction operations, steps for performing effective subtraction, and the apparatus implementing the invention.
* The preferred embodiment involves calculating a subset difference of operand exponent arguments to determine the operation on operand fractions, which allows for quicker initiation of subtraction operations.
* The invention provides a significant improvement in processing speed by ensuring that when the complete operand argument difference is determined, the correct result fraction is readily available or already being processed.
</summary>

<summary>
• The document discusses a method and system for tracking medical specimens, such as blood, using machine-readable codes to reduce mislabeling errors in medical facilities.
• It highlights the common issues in hospitals like mislabeling of specimen vials due to manual errors despite using barcodes and automation, emphasizing the need for a more reliable system.
• The proposed system uses a series of unique machine-readable codes (barcodes) linked to the patient, the order, the specimen-taker, and the specimen containers, ensuring accurate tracking and identification.
• The process involves storing these codes in a computer system, verifying their accuracy at various stages of specimen collection, and ensuring all data is related to the correct patient and order.
• The system also includes checks for the expiration date of specimen containers and generates alerts if discrepancies or errors are detected.
• Benefits of the system include enhanced accuracy in specimen handling, reduced risk of medical errors, and elimination of additional costs related to labeling and manual data entry.
• The system is adaptable for various types of medical specimens and can be implemented using standalone or networked computers with appropriate software and hardware configurations.
</summary>

<summary>
• This document relates to a patent application for a voice-activated distance measuring device intended primarily for golfers, providing distance and other relevant information through voice commands.
• The device integrates voice recognition and GPS technology to verbally deliver data such as distance to the pin, green size, and pin placement, and can be embedded in articles of clothing like hats or visors.
• It features a bone conductance vibration sensor for voice recognition, which picks up voice directly through skull vibrations, enhancing clarity and reducing background noise.
• The device can also memorize and analyze data such as club selection and shot distances to offer strategic recommendations based on past performance, using an expert system algorithm.
• Connectivity options include Bluetooth for data transfer and remote GPS functionality, allowing updates and data sharing without physical connections.
• The design includes a main printed circuit board housed within the brim of a hat, with components like a battery, speaker, and sensors integrated to ensure comfort and usability.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document discusses a semiconductor design technology focusing on design rule checks (DRC) for integrated circuits (ICs), particularly addressing the challenges in systems that include both memory and logic circuits.
* It outlines the limitations of conventional DRC methods which often result in false errors due to the application of uniform logic rules to both memory and logic circuits, which have different design requirements.
* The invention proposes a new DRC system that applies distinct sets of rules for memory and logic areas, allowing for more accurate error reporting by distinguishing between these regions.
* Customized design rules are created by modifying standard logic rules to accommodate specific requirements of memory regions, thus reducing the need for manual error checking and potential oversight of real errors.
* The document describes a system and method for implementing these customized rules using a conventional computer system equipped with software routines and libraries for DRC.
* Examples and diagrams illustrate the process of identifying and categorizing errors in different regions (logic, memory) of an IC layout, emphasizing the efficiency and accuracy of the proposed method.
* The invention is applicable not only to semiconductor industries but could also be beneficial in other fields like liquid crystal display manufacturing, where different design rules need to be applied to different types of regions on a substrate.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention relates to the use of thin substrate waveguide holograms for controlled illumination of objects like display holograms or spatial light modulators, improving upon the technology disclosed in a prior U.S. Patent application Ser. No. 07/790,516.
• The waveguide hologram (WGH) illuminator offers a compact and efficient alternative to traditional illumination systems, which typically require more space and involve multiple optical elements that can lead to stability and alignment issues.
• WGHs are designed to provide high diffraction efficiency and minimize stray light, making them ideal for applications where precise illumination is critical. They can achieve efficiencies close to 0.99 and effectively trap undiffracted light within the waveguide.
• The system can suffer from illumination depletion where light intensity decreases along the waveguide, and it may produce two diffracted beams, potentially reducing efficiency if one beam is unused.
• Solutions to address challenges include attaching the light source directly to the waveguide, using absorbing materials or mirrors to manage unwanted diffracted light, and recording the hologram non-uniformly to ensure even illumination.
• Experimental setups described include using a cubic glass prism for steep angle reference beam creation and a prism coupler for precise waveguide coupling, demonstrating the flexibility and potential of WGHs in practical applications.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document details a division of a patent application for a non-destructive testing method and apparatus for squirrel cage rotors in dynamoelectric machines, which includes measuring resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew to identify defects.
* It describes the background and need for economical and reliable testing due to potential manufacturing defects in rotors, despite high-quality mass production standards. Traditional testing methods are either costly, require the dynamoelectric machine stator, or are destructive.
* The invention involves a test apparatus with a test head that magnetizes the rotor using an alternating current, measures induced voltages and currents, and processes these measurements to determine the rotor's characteristics. The system can handle multiple rotors with automated data acquisition and processing.
* Detailed descriptions are provided for the apparatus components, operation, and data processing, including diagrams and flowcharts. The system allows for statistical analysis, automatic pass/fail determinations, and can operate efficiently with minimal operator intervention.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document discusses methods to secure mobile devices by controlling access to native resources through managed libraries and applications, particularly focusing on devices with increased computing power that can support sophisticated applications.
* It introduces a system where managed libraries with validated digital certificates can access native resources, while managed applications are restricted in their access, only able to interact with native resources through these libraries.
* The system includes a manager that authorizes access requests from applications to libraries and from libraries to native system resources, ensuring that only approved code interacts with sensitive parts of the operating system.
* The document details the process of verifying and signing applications and libraries before they are allowed to run on devices, using digital certificates to manage permissions and maintain security.
* It also describes an ecosystem where developers can submit applications to be verified and signed, and once approved, these applications can be distributed through an electronic marketplace, ensuring that only secure and approved applications are deployed on mobile devices.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to an improved identification card design that integrates an internal antenna and chip between non-rigid and rigid layers, enhancing durability and reducing production costs compared to traditional smart cards.
* The card features a core of silica-filled polyolefin with electronic components like antennas and chips embedded within, protected by layers of adhesive and shock-absorbing materials, and encased in durable polymer layers.
* The manufacturing process includes pre-shrinking the core material, applying indicia and electronic components, and laminating with high-strength adhesives and polymer layers to ensure uniform thickness and robustness, with options for additional security features and personalization.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to implementing a FIFO (First In First Out) queue in a memory, specifically in functional memories where updates are made via a "copy-on-write" method.
* Traditional FIFO queue implementations using double-ended lists are inefficient in functional memories as they require copying the entire queue for each update.
* The invention proposes a tree-shaped data structure for the queue, where updates require copying only the path from the root to the update point, reducing time and space complexity.
* Nodes in the tree have a maximum size, and the structure ensures that all leaf nodes (the lowest level nodes) are at the same hierarchy level and internal nodes are full except at the edges.
* Additions to the queue are made by adding data to the first non-full node from the bottom, and deletions are made from a leaf node at the edge of the tree.
* A header node is introduced in a preferred embodiment, containing pointers to nodes representing the start and end of the queue and the main tree structure.
* The queue can be inverted in constant time and space by updating an identifier in the header node, which changes the interpretation of the queue's direction and the tree structure.
* The invention allows for efficient updates, as additions and deletions from the queue do not require updating the entire tree structure, only specific parts.
* Detailed examples and diagrams in the document illustrate the process of adding and deleting records in the queue using the proposed tree structure.
* The memory arrangement for implementing the queue includes control logic, intermediate registers for the queue's ends, and a flag register for the inversion bit, facilitating efficient management of record pointers.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention focuses on integrating EPROM (Electrically Programmable Read-Only Memory) technology with existing DRAM (Dynamic Random Access Memory) and standard logic manufacturing processes to create embedded EPROM devices. These devices aim to enhance DRAM by providing programmable redundancy circuits, reducing the need for high voltages, and simplifying manufacturing processes, thereby lowering costs and improving yield and performance.
* Novel EPROM structures utilize DRAM storage capacitors as coupling capacitors and employ transistor stress effects to facilitate EPROM operations. This approach allows for the coexistence of DRAM and EPROM on the same wafer without additional manufacturing costs. The invention also introduces SEPROM (Stress Effect Programmable Read-Only Memory) devices, which use electrical stress damages to store data, offering potential for embedded applications and enhanced security.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a method for quickly and accurately determining the optimal feedback gain values for feedback control systems, particularly useful in applications like steering automatic guidance vehicles (AGVs).
• Feedback control typically involves detecting errors, calculating correction amounts based on these errors, and adjusting control elements (like steering angles in AGVs) accordingly, using systems such as P (proportional), PI (proportional-integral), PD (proportional-differential), and PID (proportional-integral-differential).
• The invention introduces a systematic approach to determine the optimal values of feedback gains (P, I, D) by executing a series of steps that involve setting provisional gain values, performing control tasks, measuring the resulting errors, and adjusting the gains based on the error characteristics.
• The method uses specific evaluation values to assess the suitability of gain settings, such as the ratio of the curve length of error over time (for P gain), the integral of the error (for I gain), and the integral of the absolute error (for D gain), aiming to minimize these values for optimal control performance.
• The document details two embodiments of the method: the first involves testing sections of a vehicle's course individually to determine optimal gains, while the second involves continuous running of the vehicle along the entire course to adjust and optimize gains.
• The invention allows for the adjustment of feedback gains without the need for complex multi-variable analysis, simplifying the process of optimizing feedback control systems in various applications.
• The described method is adaptable, allowing for modifications in the order of gain optimization and the specific evaluation functions used, making it versatile for different control scenarios and system requirements.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention pertains to zoom lenses designed for photographic and video cameras, focusing on achieving a high relative aperture and compact size while maintaining excellent optical performance across the zoom range.
• The zoom lens system includes a sequence of lens units with specific configurations and power arrangements, which are critical for minimizing physical size and enhancing image quality by effectively correcting various optical aberrations.
• Key design conditions and ratios for the lens elements and units are specified to optimize performance, including specific focal lengths, curvature ratios, and Abbe numbers, ensuring the correction of spherical aberrations, coma, and chromatic aberrations.
• The document details numerical examples of the lens designs, providing specific measurements and material properties for each component, demonstrating how the designs meet the set conditions for optimal performance and compactness.
</summary>

<summary>
* The document describes a method and device for detecting elementary particles such as protons, ions, electrons, neutrons, and photons using a detector that generates a charge pulse when a particle passes through.
* The charge pulse is converted into an electric signal, which is then amplified and either indicated or recorded. The amplification process involves a fast amplifier for individual signals and a slow amplifier for integrating multiple signals.
* The invention aims to overcome limitations in prior art by allowing both individual particle detection and signal integration without prior knowledge of expected signal rates, enhancing reliability in detecting small-sized signals.
* The method involves discharging the charge pulse on the low-voltage side of the detector, which simplifies the distinction of signals from background noise and prevents leakage current detection from high-voltage cables.
* The device includes a support capacitor on the low-voltage side to maintain detector functionality by compensating for the discharge at high ionization rates.
* Different configurations of amplifiers and filters (capacitors, inductors, high-pass, and low-pass filters) are used to manage signal processing based on the rate and frequency of the signals, allowing for overlapping signal rate detection.
* Special materials like diamond are suggested for the detector to enable fast charge transport at room temperature, suitable for high-resolution detection across a wide range of signal rates.
* The technology is applicable in various fields including particle accelerators, reactor installations, and medical diagnostic devices like X-ray and CT scanners, offering both individual and integrated particle detection capabilities.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention pertains to an improved apparatus for automatically spin checking driven disc assemblies in friction clutches, primarily used in vehicles to connect rotational power sources to mechanisms like transmissions.
• Traditional clutches involve a cover connected to a flywheel on the engine crankshaft, a pressure plate that moves axially, and a shift lever assembly operated by a foot pedal to engage or disengage the clutch.
• The driven disc assembly, positioned between the pressure plate and the flywheel, includes a hub and a support plate with friction elements. Its engagement or disengagement by the pressure plate facilitates or interrupts power transmission.
• Previous testing fixtures for measuring disc assembly warpage involved manual operations and were inefficient in production environments, lacking external indicators for test results.
• The new apparatus features an enclosure with a stationary and a movable ring, a torque motor, and electronic sensors to measure distances and movement, enhancing automation and efficiency in testing.
• The system automatically moves the movable ring to engage the disc assembly, applies torque, and measures the distance at which the disc begins to rotate, determining if the warpage is within acceptable limits.
• The apparatus includes a microprocessor-controlled system that manages the servo motor and torque motor, processes sensor signals, and provides visual feedback to the operator.
• The control system follows a specific sequence to ensure accurate testing, including rapid initial engagement, gradual disengagement, and precise measurement of rotation and distance.
• The invention aims to streamline the testing process, reduce manual labor, and provide clear, immediate feedback on the quality of the driven disc assemblies, with potential applications in statistical process control.
</summary>

<summary>
• This document relates to a patent application that claims priority from a U.S. Provisional Patent Application titled “Contourlet Appearance Model” filed on October 5, 2012.
• The invention described is supported by the U.S. government under specific Army Research Office grants, indicating potential government rights in the technology.
• The technology pertains to the field of image processing, specifically focusing on face age-estimation using methods, systems, and software designed for this purpose.
• The technology addresses the challenge of accurately estimating age from facial images, which is complicated by factors like facial variations due to gender, ethnicity, and environmental influences.
• The patent details a method involving a contourlet appearance model (CAM) algorithm that processes image data to estimate age by generating and analyzing feature vectors related to facial landmarks.
• Different implementations of the technology include methods for extracting facial features, mapping these features to age groups, and machine-readable storage mediums containing instructions for executing these methods.
• The document includes descriptions of training systems for face age-estimation, illustrating how landmarked face images are used to train models that can differentiate between age groups and estimate ages.
• The technology utilizes machine learning techniques such as Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Support Vector Regression (SVR) to classify faces into age groups and predict age based on extracted features.
• The patent application includes diagrams and descriptions of the computing systems and software architecture necessary to implement the face age-estimation methods, highlighting the flexibility and adaptability of the system across different computing platforms.
</summary>

<summary>
• The document discusses a matrix display device designed to display two merged images from different sources, which may have varying definitions, and is particularly useful for applications requiring image merging such as night vision and infrared imaging.
